remixed_from.author: dkj4linux
remixed_from.title: MPCNC 2826/2822 Brushless RC Motor Foam Cutter

title: Needle Cutter for MPCNC (Newer mount)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Quick and dirty taller version of needle cutter with new style MPCNC mount. Should work, but may have to make some holes.cuts in the back plate to access the mounting screws. Confirmed to work by one person once they made some clearance holes.

Will need to be printed with support due to the way the mount is designed. I'm still trying to find time to work up a better version that doesn't need support to add to my parametric needle cutter - but this should be workable until I get to that.

title: Chemistry Customized 12 dice
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After trying to find Chemistry dice set for ages ( d4 - d20) with no luck, I figured it was time to start making and customizing some dice on the site. This is my first attempt so it may not be so print friendly but it is worth a shot.

If some of you are not familiar then this is the Symbol/Element/Number relation!

H-Hydrogen-1
He-Helium-2
Li-Lithium-3
Be-Beryllium-4
B-Boron-5
C-Carbon-6
N-Nitrogen-7
O-Oxygen-8
F-Fluorine-9
Ne-Neon-10
Na-Sodium-11
Mg-Magnesium-12

title: Straw Connectors Building Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Fun and educational engineering tool for students of all ages. Affordable, sturdy, and useful. Create structures and learn about architecture.
Exp.: Bridges, Building structures, and anything else, only limited by one's imagination.
Great to introduce engineering at a young age!

Printer:

XYZ Davinci Jr. 1.0 Wireless

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Excellent or High

Infill:

30% Honeycomb

Notes:

Supports were used so the holes for the straws don't collapse. If the small holes on the side of the brace for the paper clips don't print, the diameter is 0.04 in, so you can drill out the holes if they don't print.

After Printing

After Printing, some minimal sanding is required, and a pair of needle nose tweezers are needed to pull the supports out of the holes. The tiny holes for paperclips to secure the straw may not have printed correctly and can be drilled out or poked out.

How I designed this

I designed this when I was thinking about entering the remix challenge, and I thought I could take the PVC pipe connector and make it smaller, for straws, so engineering classes can use it for building projects and all sorts of things.
NGSS CCSS

Size Specifications Paperclip hole diameter: 0.04 in
Straw hole diameter: 0.255 in
Brace Body Square measurement: 0.355 in square

Lesson Plan/Activity Students will create a structure with straws in a given amount of time. The structure will hold weight, be sturdy, and show the students different patterns of architectural style. Can also be used for younger students as well.

Materials Needed -Straws
-Scissors
-Sandpaper
-Needle Nose Tweezers
-Paperclips
-3D printed parts (files attached above)

comments.author: deathscrowbar

description.text:
Made a lamp. Its based on another lamp I had sitting on my desk, but greatly simplified. Printed the shade in "transparent" pla and it seems to provide about the right amount of shade.
Bought the other parts needed (bulb socket, cord, and arm to hold the shade) as a kit from hardware store.

It looks nice enough that my wife doesn't complain about it being used and displayed.

Coworker requested a replacement nub. Seemed fairly straightforward. Took me about an hour and 5 iterations to get perfect fit. Measuring soft rubber with a caliper is a wee bit hard.

Innermost square peg is 4x4mm, outerbit is 4.5x4.5mm. OD is 7.5mm, top OD is 8mm. The top concavity is from a sphere around 25mm R. Everything was done with simple bool add and subtract.

The blue is from when I had it 3.75mm tall, the green is the final 3.5mm tall.
Printed in tpu. Works as well as the original. Blue is alchement tpu, green is hatchbox tpu. Can be printed with or without a raft. I found using a raft gave a better bottom layer.

description.text:
I liked the overall design aspects of the source, I added some changes for functionality;

Lightened the chassis a bit here and there, added holes for the LED wires to pass to camera bay, added some zip tie slots to secure any equipment in the forward section behind the camera bay. I am printing the complete file ATM, will post assembled pictures soon. I may have to redesign the tail section some , but I will hold out hope that it works as the designer intended. I hope you like my remix and check back for any revisions as I R & D this bad boy!

Edited file shortly after I uploaded it to fix a few little errors I saw, should be all good now!

I just added a new revision on the arms, much lighter and better thrust pass through!

12-18: The chassis printed good for a mockup, but I think I will change perimeters to 2 to help fill around the holes better, along with a slight infill increase to 40 next try. All other parts are printing now, if only my equipment were to arrive! ;(

12-19: After printing all the components the weight comes in at 100 grams!....very heavy so...Again I have redesigned the frame and other components as to shave off grams. While I was in there I completely redesigned the tail section using a 5x10 bearing in the rear mount to help the rotation quality of the tail motor mount, which now is secured to the servo plate by 2 screws. The shaft and servo plate are indexed. Chassis was also redesigned to accommodate new tail section and now needs no supports. I am printing a new set for further R & D...Cheers

Update: Updated Chassis and all components now weigh 70 grams, much better now!

Update 12-22: I re-designed the tail section again using some parts from the Triforce design. I think this one is going to be the beta, only 58 grams for the whole craft now;ABS @ 30% infill and very strong. So enjoy and Happy Holidays!

comments.text: Yeah, this is a great idea but you need two exact copies and positioning the rods perfectly perpendicular to both the x-rod and the bottom rod is really difficult (if not impossible). Measurements done with a precision metal ruler proved to be much more exact (to a tolerance of about +/- 1/4mm). Using the rods I get a tolerance of +0.5mm which is unacceptable, in my opinion. Still a great design. Cheers.

author: faberdasher

title: Removable Bed Levelling Probes for Anycubic Kossel Linear

description.text:
Simple removable bracket (now with two different versions: V1 & V2) for attaching a microswitch to the effector plate on a Kossel printer (Anycubic Linear) for bed levelling. This is designed to fit a 7mm thick effector plate. The slot in the bracket is 7.5mm, and it can be clamped in place by fitting an M3x8 screw and M3 nut in the bracket. The bracket needs to be removed manually after levelling is completed.

It's designed to suit a 20mm wide microswitch (20mm x 10mm x 7mm / 0.78" x 0.4" x 0.3") with 2.5mm diameter mounting holes.

Here's are some videos of the V2 probe in action with two different versions of Marlin:
https://youtu.be/_jQKfFPhQAI (Marlin 1.1.5)
https://youtu.be/4mFnbtlPe-g (older version: Marlin 1.1.0-RC8)

Additional parts required:

  • 1x 20mm microswitch
  • 1x M3x8 screw (socket headed cap screw ideally, for use with an Allen key)
  • 1x M3 nut
  • 2x M2.5x15 screws
  • 2x M2.5 nuts

There are two different versions: V1 and V2. The smaller V1 positions the switch near the blower fan. The larger V2 puts the switch directly beneath the nozzle.

When V1 is mounted on the side of the effector nearest the blower fan, the offsets between the switch and hot end on the Anycubic Kossel Linear are approximately (X=-9, Y=29, Z=-2.7).

In contrast, the much larger V2 is mounted in the same position as V1 above, but has an offset of approximately (X=0, Y=0, Z=-24.1) The advantage of V2 is that it allows a much larger area of the bed to be probed within the limited printing radius available.

I wired the microswitch as NO, and connected to the Z_MIN endstop input. To make it easy to connect/disconnect, I used some 0.1" pin header and heat shrink to make a small 2-pin connector.

To get auto level probing to work in Marlin, I had to set X,Y & Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING all true. I also had to reduce the DELTA_PROBEABLE_RADIUS to 60mm inside the DELTA_PRINTABLE_RADIUS. The X,Y & Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER were also set up to suit the probe position.

The Anycubic firmware is based on Marlin 1.0.0, and I modified that to save/restore the nonlinear bed levelling matrix from EEPROM and to survive through G28. This makes it possible to use G29 to probe the bed, then M500 to save the matrix to EEPROM, and it gets restored on startup. Default settings can be restored with M502 then M500. Initially I created two GCode files on the SD card to run the auto-level and store to the EEPROM, so it can be done by "printing" those files from SD. However, in the more recent Marlin version linked below, there's a "Level Bed" menu option and another in option in Control Menu called "Store Memory" stores the settings to EEPROM.

It's also possible to introduce a small Z offset during G29. For example, for an additional 0.2mm clearance you can use G29 Z0.2 which adjusts the offset between the probe and the nozzle. Alternatively, in the Marlin menu you can adjust the Z probe offset slightly.

Update: to adjust the Z offset, I'm now using M206 (which has to be done before G28) in the Cura start G-code. For example: M206 Z-0.1 will lift the nozzle 0.1mm above the bed.
To make it use the auto-level data, add M420 S1 to the start G-code, after G28.

The modified Marlin firmware is here, in case it helps anyone. The individual changes to the original source code are visible in the commit log. The first link is to a recent fork of Marlin 1.1.0-RC8 which I've modified to suit the Anycubic Kossel Linear with a heated bed, and with modifications to store/restore the bilinear bed levelling matrix in EEPROM. I've used this version for quite a few prints now, with no real issues, so I've created a "tag" and will leave this alone as a "known good" version. I suggest trying this one first:
https://github.com/jam3sward/Marlin/releases/tag/1.1.0-RC8-Anycubic-Linear
If you're interested in a more recent (but less tested) Marlin build, there's a link to my development version further down.

Please bear in mind you will have to make a few changes to the configuration to suit your printer. The best way is to compare the configuration of this version against your old firmware source code (using a "diff" tool).

I've added a printer log file with an example of the bed calibration matrix for my own printer.

In general, auto-levelling is not well documented or easy to set up - make sure to read through the comments section - it has some useful clues which may help you!

I've noticed a couple of issues with Marlin 1.1.0-RC8 on this printer. These are minor annoyances, and not show-stopping:

  1. Selecting "Stop Print" during printing may crash the head. Because I no longer trust it, my workaround is to select "Pause Print" instead, then "Auto Home" then "Stop Print". That works fine.
  2. For the first print after powering on, after issuing M420 S1 the print head moves really slowly towards the bed (as if calling M420 S1 causes it to ignore the feed rate setting). It resumes normal speed once it starts printing. If you print the same file again, the head moves towards the bed at full speed, so this only seems to happen on the first print.

New developments on a branch from 1.1.5:
Having frozen the 1.1.0-RC8 version above, I've created a new branch for development based on 1.1.5 here:
https://github.com/jam3sward/Marlin/tree/1.1.5-Anycubic-Linear
The new 1.1.5 branch has some major advantages:

  • Support for the new Unified Bed Leveling (UBL)
  • Support for G33 Delta Auto Calibration

If you upload the 1.1.5 firmware, make sure you use M502 then M500 to reset EEPROM to defaults.

After fitting the probe, you can check it is working as follows:

M119  ; this should show "z_min: open" when the probe is open
; push the switch with your finger...
M119  ; this should now show "z_min: TRIGGERED" when the probe is pushed

To configure Unified Bed Levelling you can do the following:

G28        ; home
G29 P1     ; automatically probe the bed

G29 T      ; view the results
G29 S1     ; save the UBL auto level data to EEPROM
G29 F 10.0 ; set fade height for correction at 10mm
G29 A      ; activate UBL auto level system
M500       ; save current setup to EEPROM

There's more information on UBL here: http://marlinfw.org/docs/features/unified_bed_leveling.html
There are LCD menu commands for UBL also (which I haven't tried yet).

Here's an example of how to use the new Delta Auto Calibration in 1.1.5. Make sure you have fitted and tested the probe first:

G33    ; perform delta auto calibration
; check the displayed results and, if they look sensible...
M500   ; save them to EEPROM

More information on Delta Auto Calibration here:
http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/G033.html

I've encountered one issue with Marlin on larger prints: if you try and print outside the UBL mesh, it raises the effector on Z until it hits the end stops and has to be powered off. This seems to exist on later versions of Marlin, see the following issues:
https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin/issues/9147 https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin/issues/8723 https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin/issues/9344
Some of the later bug-fix releases may fix this, but I haven't tried them yet.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Linear

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height, 0.8mm shell thickness

Infill:

20%

comments.author: peaberry

comments.text: The MANUAL_Z_HOME_POS on mine is set to 323.4, which is about 38mm difference. My guess is that, because of this, your firmware probably thinks the printer is shorter than it actually is, which could explain why it starts probing with the probe so high off the bed. For example, if it tries to position the probe at 15mm above the bed, it might actually be at 15+38 = 53mm above the bed. However, after auto-calibration, this offset probably appears in all the correction values, so that probably takes out the big offset and enables you to print.
comments.author: 1Ghasthunter1

comments.text:
The first issue with the "tilted plane" could be an issue with calibration, mechanical or limit switch?
The second issue reminds me of an issue I have seen (possible bug?) with this version of Marlin: I found that if you select "Stop Print" from the menu it will usually crash into the bed. However, selecting "Pause Print" is OK. So if I need to abort a print, I always do this instead: "Pause Print"... then "Auto Home"... then "Stop Print".
Regarding the third issue, after the head has crashed, if you haven't homed again it will have lost track of the stepper positions, so you would need to Auto Home again. However, I guess that's probably not the reason as printing the file would presumably auto home again anyway?

comments.author: Rahl

comments.text: Hi there - G-code files are simply text files with the appropriate commands in them. For Marlin you could use Notepad (or similar text editor) to create a file called "level_bed.gcode", then type "G29" in the file, and save it. When you print this file from SD card, it will start probing the bed to measure the auto-levelling grid (because G29 is the G-code for Auto Bed Leveling on Marlin). Similarly, putting the code "M500" in a G-code file will cause it to store the settings to EEPROM when you print that G-code file. However, there's no need on recent versions of Marlin, because it already has options in the menu to run auto-levelling and to store settings to EEPROM.

comments.text:
Regarding the "Heating failed" message I think this is because the firmware is configured for a heated bed, but you don't have a heated bed. In your first photo you can see in the top right it says H-26/0º which means the printer thinks the bed temperature is -26ºC. Have a look inside Marlin\Configuration.h and change TEMP_SENSOR_BED to 0 as follows:
#define TEMP_SENSOR_BED 0
comments.author: Rahl

comments.text: TEMP_SENSOR_BED 0 helped me to solve that problem. Thanks you.

comments.text:
Hi there
It sounds like the probe offsets or probeable radius may be wrong.
You have the larger "Plus" model (230x270mm workspace) whereas I have the standard model (180x300 workspace) so you could probably increase the probeable radius.
Also, there are two versions of the probe V1 and V2. The Marlin source on Github currently has the offsets for V2.
For V1 my offsets were -9, 29 and -2.7
For V2 my offsets are 0,0,-24.1
You can see the relevant settings at the top of this commit:
https://github.com/jam3sward/Marlin/commit/6c3f9ec3345f1aa1488ae25bad1c717b982378ec
Hope this helps?
V2 works better than V1 for me, because it allows more of the bed area to be probed. I found that my printer has nowhere near the 180mm radius claimed by the manufacturer...
comments.author: deosys

A topo map of the Cathedral range in Yosemite NP. Vertical height is 200% of actual 'cause that's how it feels when you are climbing. Data set is 1/3 arc sec. from the National Map. Kudos to gluetolf for sharing a good technique (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27194). Great for visualizing the Cathedral Traverse route. Complete instructions on how to make models from digital elevation data can be found on my blog at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1

5.5 hr build on a FlashForm Creator.  Sliced in MakerWare.  Printed with nasty looking JET ABS.  Too bad they don't make more natural looking colors.  
You can print it vertical to get a smoother texture, but I prefer the horizontal print because the extrusion lines mimic the contour line on a map.

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Filament Guide/Cleaner ClipOn

description.text:
This is a remix of two very nice filament guides, and is made of:
1) ClipOn holder (by Area51): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1940114
2) ClipOn loop (by Area51): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1940114
3) Threaded filter outer shell (by Kezat): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:497764
4) ClipOn Threader filter central part (this thing, using Area51's idea and the Kezat central part)
5) ClipOn closed loop (this thing, a modified Area51's loop)

The remix is intended for Prusa i3 MK2 frame. Just attach the holder to the top of the frame and, depending on the filament or need, choose the loop guide or the spongy dust cleaner.

I have also added a closed loop for those very brittle filaments which may break by catching on the slit of the open loop. My suggestion is to use the closed loop... if you forget to put in the filament, replace it with the open loop clip!

Prusa i3 MK2

The parent project "Lego Conveyor Belt" is finished and I realized my belt was broke... I decided to spend the morning dabbling in the world of HIGH FASHION.

Be THE hit at the next convention with this fully customizable and durable ABS belt. Pull out that box of Legos... With a bit of creativity (and a good block selection) you supply the message that people will notice!

disclaimer: in this design the buckle plate also fastens your belt. This belt is for fashion, not function. Only use belt with pants that don't require a belt or the belt won't be the reason you're so popular at that next business meeting.

There are more details about how the links for a belt on the parent project.

Have fun and build revision 2.0 by adding the female lego side to the belt. Revision 2.0 is infinitely adjustable in 1/2" increments!

title: FT Mini power pod firewall for quad motors

description.text:
This is a set of firewalls designed for mounting a race quad motor on the FT mini power pod. One has a 16mm x 19mm hole pattern (for 220x size motors). The other has a 12mm x 16mm hole pattern (for 180x size motors). The firewall is 4mm thick, both for strength, and so that typical mounting bolts should be the correct length.

Sample picture shows a 2204 motor mounted to firewall.

Sept 21, 2017: Added a version with a 12x12mm hole pattern to fit motors like the RacerStar BR1806.

Sept 23, 2017: Added SCAD model so all parameters can be configured by the user via the Customizer App. This is a work in progress since this is the first time I've ever tried this.

Oct 8, 2017: Added tabs to the Customizer version in an effort to keep the firewall attached to the power pod a bit better. If you don't want the tabs, just set tab length to 0. The default value of 5 for the tab position and the foam thickness should be just right if you're using Dollar Tree or Flite Test foam board. Adjust accordingly if you are using a different thickness of foam.

Printer:

Maker Select v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50-100%

Notes:

I set my wall, top, and bottom thicknesses to 1.2, just because of the abuse it's going to get.

comments.text: Dayve thanks for your fast response! I forgot to mention that those screws are only M2 and also shorter. Could you make the four holes 2mm in diameter and the firewall in 2 mm thickness?
comments.author: Dayve

comments.text:
Konrad,
I've been meaning to play around with OpenSCAD and the Customizer, so this was the perfect excuse. You can now click the "Open in Customizer" link just to the right of the thumbnail pics. That will allow you to define your own parameters for pretty much everything. There are no sanity checks in the model, though, so you have to make sure to not make the bolt holes run in to the center hole or the motor wire notch, etc.

author: snelleluc

description.text:
The Lulzbot Mini's standard felt pad cleaning strip works well to remove melted plastic, but often leaves a few felt fibers on the print head. Those fibers can prevent good electrical contact between the print head and bed washers, causing the G29 probe sequence to fail.

This is a re-design of the pad holder. In addition to holding the standard Lulzbot felt pad, a secondary slot holds a 71mm x 11mm strip of "Scotch Brite Non-Scratch Scour Pad". Adding a successive wipe across the non-fiber scouring pad removes any residual fibers, greatly improving reliability of the G29 sequence.
https://youtu.be/YO0xHRwP1jk

You will need to cut a 71mm x 11mm strip of Scotch Brite non-scratch scour pad for the secondary slot. This material can be found at most supermarkets, although I purchased from Amazon (link below). You can cut about (13) of the 71mm x 11mm strips from a single pad, and the pads are sold in packs of three.
US Amazon store:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00PGETVX2
UK Amazon store:
https://www.amazon.co.uk/623S-14-Count-Scotch-Brite-Scratch-Scour/dp/B0011DO14G/

You will also need to insert a few lines of Gcode into your Lulzbot Mini's start scripts. The first and last lines shown below are from the existing script, to show where the new lines get inserted. The new lines are shown in bold:
...
G1 X115 Y172 Z-0.5 F1000 ; wipe slower and bury nozzle in cleanish area
G1 Z4 ; -- raise z prepare for move to secondary wiper
G1 X105 Y181 ; -- right end of secondary wiper
G1 Z1 ; -- Move down to pad
G1 X85 Y181.5 F4000 ; -- wipe off lint
G1 X105 Y181 F4000 ; -- wipe off lint
G1 X65 Y181.5 F4000 ; -- wipe off lint
G1 X85 Y181 Z0.5 F4000 ; -- wipe off lint
G1 X49 Y181.5 F3000 ; -- wipe off lint
G1 X69 Y181 F3000 ; -- wipe off lint
G1 X49 Y181.5 F2000 ; -- wipe off lint
G1 Z10 ; raise z
...
NOTE: The above Y positions are for firmware 1.1.5.xx. If you have firmware 1.1.0.xx or 1.0.0.xx, replace Y181 with Y182 and Y181.5 with Y182.5. (The 1.1.5 firmware changed the Y_min and Y_max by -1. You can see your firmware version by opening your print control console and sending M115 command).

The Sketchup design file is included, in case you want to make alterations. Enjoy!

comments.text: Have you experimented at all with replacing the original lulzbot pad with a green scotch-brite kitchen sponge?
comments.author: DougM

comments.text: I have.  The scotch-brite tends to be too "soft" to really get all the plastic off, particularly with "stickier" stuff like PETG or Nylon.  The original pad does a better job at that, but frequently leaves some "lint" -- hence the two-pad approach: The original gets the plastic, the scotchbrite gets the lint left behind by the original.
comments.author: DougM

comments.text: Fantastic upgrade. Will print another one in Village Plastic "Lulzbot green" when my reel arrives. One note for those ordering the scour pads through Amazon. I didn't hit the "pay now" button to quickly. Ended up buying 18 scourpads with a total of 53 euros, including 39 euros for shipping. Most expensive scour pads I ever bought :-) Anyway, these should last a lifetime!
comments.author: Marcel_X

comments.text: Glad you like it.  And it will look super in the Lulzbot green!  :-)
comments.author: Marcel_X

comments.text:
I will post a picture when I have my green version! And I like your Nema Heatsink Clamp as well.
And I'll be careful when ordering the heatsink from Amazon and check the shipping cost first :-)
comments.author: ScottW1

comments.text:
Reprinted in Lulzbot Green! Looks great.
On a side note for Mac users, to find the profiles, you need to right click on Cura and select "Show Package Contents".
And than it is basically the same path as on a Windows machine. I did paste the extra needed G-code by hand initially in Cura in full settings,
but as soon as you switch material or go back and forth between quick print and full settings, the extra G-code got lost.
Duh... my fault. Changed my .ini files of the filament I have and now it works fine in quick print mode as well.
comments.author: Marcel_X

comments.text: Any thoughts on using this on a Taz 6?
comments.author: Wallyharris

comments.text: I don't have a Taz6, but from photos I would say it should work fine.  The dual-wiper protrudes "off the bed" about 1/4", so check to make sure there is no physical obstruction and you'll be fine.   The hole pattern should be identical, I am 99% sure AO uses the exact same wiper for both the Mini and the Taz.
comments.author: Wallyharris

comments.text: Thank you for this useful upload. My own wiper holder broke while changing out the cleaning pad and this came in handy. I was wondering how you altered the G-Code to perform the second cleaning process for the nozzle?
comments.author: Cooper_Thomez

comments.text: The starting G-Code script is generally part of the material/quality profiles in your slicer.  So exactly where the files are and how to edit them depends on the slicer you are using.
comments.author: Cooper_Thomez

comments.text: Thank you for posting the original link. I appreciate it.
comments.author: ScottW1

comments.text: Thank you very much for your prompt response! I understand how it works now
comments.author: ScottW1

title: Ultimaker2 clone XY-banana block 3-point fastener
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
2017-01-13 Update: Added combo-block with 10.1mm diameter for smaller bushing. The original block is 11.2mm diameter.

So I liked the original banana block with builtin tensioner, and I also liked the upgraded block with 3 points for fastening the cross-rods.

This is a combination of the two, original banana block and the cross-rod mount from the XY-block 1.01-upgrade. The mount is also remade to exactly 6mm since I prefer to use a drillbit after printing to get a perfect fit. The bushing-diameter is 11.2mm to fit a 11mm bushing snug.

Also included is the spacer I used instead of PTFE since I didn't have any.

A adapter to make the Budaschnozzle fit the SeeMeCNC H1 extruder and acetal bearings supports.

This is a work in progress of my first mod on my SeeMeCNC H1 (http://seemecnc.com). I'm attempting to get my Budaschnozzle hotend (http://reprap.org/wiki/LulzBot/Budaschnozzle) fit the actual Steve's Extruder and acetal bearings supports provided with my H1. This is part of the HX1-Mod project, hosted at GitHub : https://github.com/hcross/HX1-Mod I also added a Sketchup file for taking precise measures of the official SeeMeCNC parts.

description.text:
I splitted the original .STL in two different objects, repaired the mesh in the handle and relocated them in the printing bed for an easier printing.

For my Hephestos I had to resize a little the blade's z-axis, from about 19cm to 17.5cm.

Printer:

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

25%-35%

Notes:

Supports: Only touching the printing bed.

Handle rafts margin: 10mm
Blade rafts margin: 15mm

Infill is really up to you. I played with infill and wall thickness up to 1,2mm

Removing supports

Even with only a density of 10% in a grid pattern, removing supports in the handle could be a pain. Use pliers, a sharp xacto blade and some sand paper to get smooth surfaces.

You will have to sand the whole prop to get a better -less poly- look. Then you can add details from the game references.

Most gearing mechanisms known today were invented decades or even centuries ago. Not so with the Eccentrically Cycloidal (EC) drive: it is so new the ink is still not dry on its patents! This 3D-printable model is made available to the public with the explicit permission of the patent holder.

This futuristically looking mechanism is very efficient and extremely compact. The gear ratio in this particular EC drive model is 1:9, an almost impossible feat for a standard involute gear pair.

For more information on EC gears, please visit http://www.ec-gearing.com.

https://youtu.be/PzTXB7pUj6w

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Hardware:

4 Metric countersunk Phillips-head M3x12 screws
2 Metric M3 nuts

Assembly Instructions:

Assembly is straightforward. Secure washer and spinner with screws. Connect leg1 and leg2 to stand with two screws and nuts. The legs can be optionally capped with bridge on top (not shown on the photos, but could be seen in the video.)
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/9l9QMz67J0c" ></iframe>

author: forest66

description.text:
Enclosure for PanelDue 4.3" (Escher3d).

The main parts are the Front and Back panels.
The rest of the parts (Back mount,Link,Rail) are optional for mounting.

UPDATE 25.02.2017
I uploaded a new version of the Front panel (Ver3).
List chagnes:

  • Side cut is now bigger, to allow MicroUSB connection to the PanelDue.
    (The MicroUSB connector is required for PanelDue firmware upgrade)
  • Front LCD cut changed to fit better the LCD screen
  • larger Reset and Erase buttons holes

Required Hardware:
M3x6 (Mate LCD screen to Front panel), Quantity : 4
M3x12 (Mate Front panel to Back plate), Quantity : 6
M3x10 (Mate Back plate to Back Mount), Quantity : 5
M4x20 (Mate Back mount to Link), Quantity : 1
M5x40 (Mate Link to Rail), Quantity : 1

M3 Nuts, Quantity : 5
M4 Nuts, Quantity : 1

Hi,
Thanks for the feedback.
The 7" PanelDue is slightly different, so scaling it up won't work.
I started to design an enclosure for it, but turns out that the enclosure was too big for my printer build plate, so I abended that design.
I am willing to send you the design files so you can continue the development.

title: Low-Poly Totodile - Dual Extrusion version
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I would love to keep sharing my projects with all of you. If you enjoy with my designs, I invite you to become a patron, you will get early access to my designs and exclusive content! Also, you can help with a small donation.

Patreon: http://www.patreon.com/flowalistik
Donations: http://www.paypal.me/flowalistik

The dual extrusion Low-Poly Totodile is designed to show all the possibilities of dual and multi extrusion 3D Printers. Based on the original Low-Poly designs, this model has been completely redesigned and optimized to be printed with two or more extruders.

This model is more complex but easier to print, and it keeps all the features from the original design: it doesn't need support material, infill or prime tower.

This design is based on Pokemon.

author: FLOWALISTIK

description.text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=021bGXrXBPY this shows a maker bot extruder on a bfb tool because of how easy it is to get parts and nozzles in the usa. i also created an adapter bracket that holds the top of the ptfe in place when clamped by the plexy glass on top. just for those bfb people that need to send out for another extruder. mine broke last week after clogging.

create 3d part from stl file, put it on top of a build ptfe and brass rod, after assembling triangle below device and clamping, make sure the ptfe is centered so the brass rod does not touch the metal triangle washer. after that wire up ni chrome wire, and use kapton tape, or do the cement again. also if you need to use new wires make sure the wires are not copper, as copper oxidizes to the extreme temp. meaning extruder never turns back on.. so use another metal wire.

comments.text:
I do not see any holes for the 3 screws that form the attachment points for
toolhead on the BfB RepMan.
So this is not an attachment for a makerbot extrudre but a way to
match a makerbot hotend to the BfB Extruder.
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: CORRECT. The attachment is from bfb and is a triangle bolted with 3 attachments, i cleaned away the cement and replaced the entire thermal barrier, as well as the heating tip and nozzle that still uses the bfb attachments.The piece here fits on top, and helps hold the PTFE  in place as well as ensure the PTFE is long enough for the bfb machine. it did this when i could not find a 1 inch tubing replacement for the Teflon tubing included with my kit. the tubing wore out, or actually blew out a hole. in the usa Teflon tubing is ordered in 50ft at a time! could not find 1 inch anywhere! but the ptfe barrier i had in stock.

title: DJI Mavic Pro Foot Extensions & Rear Foot

description.text: These are front feet extensions and a rear foot for the DJI Mavic Pro. I saw designs similar to this and designed my own in Tinkercad. They will raise the camera (measured from the bottom of the lens) from 5/8" to 1 3/4"and the rear of the craft from 7/16" to 1 5/8".

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

70%

Notes:

I printed these with PLA, with 4 top and bottom layers and 4 outer shells.

You may need to adjust the scale slightly for a tight fit on the front extensions. I found that the higher resolution and infill I printed on the test prints the looser the fit. These files are a nice tight fit on my Mavic Pro, but results may vary depending on certain printers, settings, material used, etc.

comments.text: What may I ask are you implying? I saw a design on eBay that looked to be the best option for legs and then proceeded to build my own models from scratch in tinkercad. It took me several days, a dozen or so prints of the front legs and 4 for the back to get it right. I then posted it here for others to print out themselves. The person mentioned in the post above who is selling it on Facebook admittedly took my files, tweaked them slightly and is selling for profit. comments.text: I'm not implying anything.  I'm asking if the design was yours from scratch as I am not able to understand how all the Amazon and eBay sellers managed to get them designed, made and available for sale weeks before you even listed the design here.  Therefore, if it was not your original design but you remised another then I just feel maybe it should be noted that this is a remix.  Nothing more.
comments.author: filmscum

comments.text: From what I understand and I'm sure you will correct me if I'm wrong but a remix is taking a design (i.e.files) from sites like this and remixing it to tweak certain things to create new designs. And when doing so they are asked to mention the original designer out of courtesy. I visually looked at a photo on eBay then went into Tinkercad and built my own models, from scratch, which were different from the ones I looked at. So to answer your question yes this design is mine from scratch, I didn't start with someone's files. And more so I put them on here for others (like you) to print off for free, not making a penny? The OP of this thread simply noted that someone is making money off a remix of my design. I contacted them and they admitted as much. I didn't remix anything.

I was probably just being really picky, but I could not find any spool holders I really liked. And the ones I liked was not designed for my wooden prusa.

Most of the filament spools I have are 20 cm diameter, but I designed the holder so you can move one of the rod in if you have a smaller spool. It takes spools up to 100mm wide.

Note that there are different set of the holders. One named 5_5mm that fits my geeetech prusa i3 wood, and one named 8mm that fits the geeetech prusa i3 acrylic.

As minimum you will need to print the two holders and two spools. It is not absolutely necessary to print the spacers, but it is recommended for the life of the bearings.

Besides from the printed parts, you will also need

  • 2 rods. I designed for 8mm rods
  • 4 ball bearings. I designed for 608zz, but you can probably find alternatives

Optionally, but recommended some way to keep the bearings in place. The obvious choice is M8 nuts on the threaded rod, but for test I also printed some "locks" in TPU for the straigt rod.

title: Keystone Jack Punchdown Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a better way to punch down keystone jacks rather than holding them in my hand (which quickly gets tiresome) or using a scrap of wood etc., so I created this holder. I rounded the corners to add comfort and reduce fatigue. It works equally well on a hard surface or in the hand, and really comes in handy when working on a ladder or in awkward situations. Takes up very little room in your toolkit and you can carry it in your pocket comfortably all day.

The original version (v.02) works with Leviton keystones. I added a newer version (v.03-cm) which works with Cable Matters keystones as well as Leviton keystones. Version 03 was done completely in OpenSCAD using minkowski to round the corners.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

low/3mm layers

Infill:

15% wide honeycomb

Basic design in OpenSCAD, saved as .stl, imported .stl into 123D, converted to a solid, then used the fillet tool to round the edges. Doing it all in OpenSCAD with minkowski would have taken more time.

comments.text: I made a way more complicated and less-effective design of this type of thing about 8 months ago, this is way better! It works fine with the Leviton jacks, but I have some other Cat5e keystones with zip tie brackets on the back that don't quite fit. Learning OpenSCAD today to modify it, thanks for the design!
comments.author: WereWalrus

comments.text: This works great with Leviton jacks.  I also tried some cheaper Monoprice jacks but unfortunately they were just 1mm too long to fit into the housing.

description.text:
Watch here: https://youtu.be/s5pw_dprOyw

It's time to add Terrance and Phillip to my list of South Park characters. We had a noticeable absence of farts on our tree. So I fixed that.

I created these in Fusion 360 using sketches to trace an image of them. Then I extruded the different areas to create a physical separation in the model without having to use paints.

After I printed them out my wife painted them using acrylics paints with a paintbrush and a sponge that helps apply color quicker.

description.text:
Seen a couple of handmade spinners that are revolver shaped out of wood and figured that I wanted one just like that.

I made the bullet caps separate from the main body of the spinner because I couldn't get a good print from it. Just super glued them onto the spinner.

For the thumb grips, I used:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1935683

Still pretty new to the 3D printing scene, and I know that I gotta fine tune the leveling of the bed to get a clean seamless 1st layer. Hence the lines in my prints. Especially in the last photo (Dark Purple spinner with the caps on the bearing).
I noticed that when I print using a raft it comes out a bit nicer but the lines are still visible.

Really curious to how nice it would look if it was all seamless, so if you print one, be sure to show me in the "I made one!"

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

Notes:

Actually printed on a Maker Select V2.

print_settings.Notes:: Use Superglue/CA to glue the parts on.

description.text:
Keridel's Keyring is a fantastic print and my daughter asked me to have the top layer a different color, so I cut this into two layers so the top can be printed in a different color such as glow/luminous. She loves it, so we wanted to share!

My first attempt was with dual-extrusion and I tried to save the file that way, but it just wasn't happening. So instead, there are 2 files...top and bottom separately so you can print them separately and then glue together. In fact, it seems even better this way - and much simpler too!

Print the top layer without fill (solid) for best effect if you're using glow-filament. Bottom should be done with 15-50% fill (I did 15%).

Makes great gifts! Please post your makes!

If you like this, please feel free to tip the original maker (Keridel) and check out his other keyrings! :)

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.14mm

Infill:

0% Top, 15%-50% bottom

Notes:

I printed mine using FlashForge Blue PLA for the bottom at 215C, ESun Luminous Blue PLA for the top, Bed at 50C.

Use Superglue/CA to glue the parts on.

author: perridan

title: Kossel 2020 XL heated bed holder / adapter

description.text: I had the heated bed mounted to my printer MacGyver style, using clamps to mount the bed to the frame and bulldog clips to hold the glass to the bed. See the photo's. It made the printer look cheap, and I could not wire up the heated bed because its connections were clamped to the printer frame. These adapters solve all the problems above. With these adapters, you can wire up the heated bed, and the printer instantaneously looks 500€ more expensive :-)

The parts you need
  • 3x heated bed adapter (one with space for the wires)
  • 3x heated bed adapter cap
  • Kossel XL
  • Round heated bed with ears for Delta Rostock / Reprap Ø 265 mm
  • Glass plate Ø 260 mm
  • 6x M3, 8 mm screws
  • 6x M3 nut
  • 12x M4, 12 mm countersunk screws
  • 6x M4 nut
  • 6x M4 (hammer) T-nut
Build instructions

Solder a thermistor to the heated bed and fixate it with kapton tape. Wire up the heated bed and thermistor to the electronics of your printer.

Place the M3 and M4 nuts in the adapters. Mount the heated bed to the adapters using the M3 bolts. Mount the heated bed with the adapters to the printer frame using the M4 bolts and (hammer) T-nuts. Mount the glass plate using the adapter caps and M4 nuts.

Note: the pile of parts in the last photo were created during the prototyping process.

If you only use the heated bed for PLA (recommend bed temperature 20-35C) you could use PLA, otherwise I recommend using PETG or ABS for the adapters.

Usage

Calibrate you printer before usage! Remember that your bed is lifted around 5 mm.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this in PLA, print speed 4800mm/min, 0.2mm layer height, 50% infill. You could play around with the infill. Extrusion width 0.4mm.

title: BBQ Thermometer Holder - Maverick Redi Chek ET-733

description.text: This is a stand for the Redi Chek Maverick barbecue digital thermometer (model ET-733). It has a flat base and an angled slot that fits both the primary and remote thermometers. I found the supplied stand for the outdoor/primary thermometer way too flimsy and it kept blowing over in the wind (it blew off the bbq a few times and nearly broke). This stand is much more stable.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I printed this in PLA, print speed 4800mm/min, 0.2mm layer height, 50% infill. You could play around with the infill. Extrusion width 0.4mm.

I designed this using a pair of digital calipers to measure the thermometer and added about 2mm to the width/depth to allow for any printing variation. I then used Autodesk Fusion360 to make a couple of simple boxes (one for the base and one to hold thermometer), angled the top one back and used the Loft function to fill in the space beneath/in front. I had no idea if the Loft would work but it worked perfectly and saved me having to worry about ugly supports under the angled box. Very happy with result. Exported to .stl opened in Simplify3D, transferred to HD card and printed on Makergear M2. Total time from idea to finished print was about 3 hours!

author: drandybuck

print_settings.Notes:: If you want to print as 100 percent, use the smallest nozzle you can. Otherwise scale it up 50 percent.

description.text:
This is a printable business card sized menorah that can be easily mailed as a fun gift.

Because the 'flames' are not attached, you can add them one by one.

This is a print with FINE detail, so a nozzle smaller than .4 will be desired. I printed with a .25 and it came out lovely.

Printer:

rerap i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Notes:

If you want to print as 100 percent, use the smallest nozzle you can. Otherwise scale it up 50 percent.

Decided to print these together, so I didn't have to worry about spacing, alignment and all that when I assembled the Y carriage.
I also shaved the tops of the bearing holders off, as I think they are unnecessary.

It hits the outer limits of a prusa (195.41mm at longest point).
Make sure to enable Skirt in skeinforge to see if it will fit on your platform before it starts the actual print!

title: tempered glass helping hand (iphone 6/s)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Your helping hand for tempered glass

Everyone knows the struggle to place your tempered glass to protect your phone screen.
You just have one chance to place it right. If you messed up, you'll need to buy a new one and it can cost more than 5 dollars. So here is the solution for placing a tempered glass on an iphone 6 or 6s and it will work for your iphone 7 as well.

You'll need to slide your phone in this part and now its very easy to attach your tempered glass perfectly. There is only one way to place it.

This is created for the RemixChallenge

I was inspired by Apple TV Remote Case .
You need to take care of your electronic devices. My model (helping hand for tempered glass) is inspired by the minimalistic way to create a gadget to extend the lifetime of my apple device. Here it's the screen of my Iphone 6.

description.text: I designed this to hold a class set of USB Thumb Drives for my students, I ended up not printing it all the way to the top,

print_settings.Notes:: The sides and back walls are 2mm thick and are meant to be solid, so set print width and number of perimeters for optimal results for your print head. For example, with a .4mm print head set print width to .5mm and use at least two perimeters.

title: Milwaukee M12 battery holder and wall mount

description.text:
This is a battery holder and wall mount for the Milwaukee M12 battery system.

Available for download are two models for one or three batteries - both can hold extended capacity (XC) batteries. On request, I can provide other STLs for 1-3 batteries with narrow or wide spacing (which accommodates the XC battery), or 4 batteries with narrow spacing only.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro (2016)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The sides and back walls are 2mm thick and are meant to be solid, so set print width and number of perimeters for optimal results for your print head. For example, with a .4mm print head set print width to .5mm and use at least two perimeters.

Designed in FreeCAD 0.16

I designed a rough model of the battery to use for the cutouts. From there, it was just the matter of tweaking and printing out tests to get the spacing and battery rotation right.

The CAD file has multiple cutout templates that I experimented with before deciding to upload just two versions to Thingiverse. If you want to make use of these other layouts, you can do the following in FreeCAD (or just ask and I'll upload an STL for you):

  1. Switch to part workbench
  2. If not visible already, open the Combo View panel (View --> Panels --> Combo View). Select the Model tab
  3. Delete last three steps (Chamfer, Fillet##, Cut).
  4. After deleting the cut, select the Battery object in the Combo view and hit the space bar to hide the cutout template (you don't need it anymore)
  5. Double click BasePad and edit the length to whatever number is noted on the particular battery cutout you want. This will change the length of the object to fit whatever number of batteries you want. For example, if you wanted a 2-bay narrow holder, then type in 114mm.
  6. In the Combo View, select TopEdgeFillet_LastBeforeCut, then CTRL-click on whatever battery cutout you decided (to continue the example in the last step, you would select "Battery_2_narrow (BasePad 114)")
  7. Apply a boolean cut. You should have a usable model now with the proper cutouts.
  8. Switch to Part Design workbench
  9. Select the top face of the object (where the holes are) and apply a fillet of 1.5mm. This will smooth out the edges on top.
  10. Select any edge on the bottom lip of the battery holder hole(s) and apply a chamfer of 1mm (for multiple batteries, CTRL-click to select one edge from each hole). This helps smooth out the bottom edge of the hole.
  11. To export your object as an STL, select your final object in the Combo View, then go to File --> Export

The bottom chamfer isn't strictly necessary, but it might help out if your bottom layers get squished outward or expanded.

comments.text: Just what I need simple yet functional nice work.
comments.author: VK3NFI

description.text: Connecting rod for the Original Prusa i3 MK2 filament spool holders/mount. Meant to be a press fit (printed with little to no shrinkage in PLA) on to the original Prusa arms and connect them. Part is 16mm ID, 24mm OD, and 120mm in length.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printed with a 4mm brim to aid with bed adhesion. I went with a lower in-fill percentage, but set the Slic3r to do solid in-fill every 50 layers. Printed in PLA it fit the Original Prusa arms perfectly.

Here it is used in combination with the Prusa i3 MK1 & MK2 Spool Holder V3 - Quick Change by IsmaelPR1. It's not touching the spool, but is there to provide support in an emergency if the spool was bumped off.

Designed two cylinders in the Windows 10 3D modeling software. One was 24mm in diameter and the other 16mm in diameter. They were both set to 120mm in height, centered upon each other, and then the smaller cylinder was subtracted from the larger.

title: Fuel gauge for nema 17 stepper motor

description.text: This is a fuel gauge that I originally cretaed as a joke but then realized that it had some legitimate uses.  Use it with a nema 17 stepper motor to create a working analog fuel gauge, battery gauge or whatever else you want to monitor.

1) Print gauge.
2) Print needle.
3) Attach stepper motor. You may have to trim your stepper shaft or create a spacer if the needle is to far away from the gauge. I've included the Sketchup file so you can modify or create a gauge with different lettering. I like to see one printed in black with glow in the dark lettering and needle.

author: adk

print_settings.Notes:: Model has notches at corners where model rests on the build plate. This makes it easy to remove the print when it has completed.

description.text:
The trash bag fell into the recycle bin again. I used the little hook on the side to tighten the bag's edge around the edge of the bin. To no avail. When I added even a little bit of recycled material, the bag's edges slipped off and it fell in once again.

To be fair, this does not happen too often. I think the quality of this particular bag was not very good and the trash bag was rather thin.

Why they make bins like this that are deeper than the actual trash bags you would put in is beyond me!

I decided to design this support that you can place in the bottom of the bin so that the bottom of the bag has something to rest on.

The dimensions are such that you could put two of these next to one another at the bottom of a wider bin for the best functionality. But one probably would be good enough.

Is this the best way to handle this problem? Probably not.

It only prints on a printer with a large build volume.
It takes a long time to print.
It uses a good amount of filament too!

You can use it for a crate or a basket too. But you could probably buy one that is cheaper and with no wait time of hours and hours!

But we all print the strangest things! Despite all this, I found it fun to design and print this!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Model has notches at corners where model rests on the build plate. This makes it easy to remove the print when it has completed.

title: Duet & Duet Wifi Case w/ Cooling
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
WARNING - Work in process. This is in second revision after first print test.

Designed to fit Duet Wifi (https://www.duet3d.com) and earlier versions which all share the same hole mounting pattern. This case has been very carefully thought out by an engineer with extensive fixture design experience. Please provide suggestions and I will make further revision updates!

Features:
Wire duct style wire management
Dual 40mm fan cooling of board underside (per Duet recommendation)
Passive cooling vents on top of board
Ability to add cover - clear acrylic or printed.
All holes will self tap with M3 machine screws. No need to use nuts or taps!

Additional components required:
Top cover mount (for plexiglass) - M3x12MM screws & washers - Qty 4
Acrylic sheet - if choosing clear cover instead of printed (fab drawing included)
Circuit board mount - M3x12MM screws - Qty 2-4
Fan mount - M3 screws (length depends on your fan size) Qty 4-8
40MM Computer Fans - Qty 2

Changes 12/20/2016
Added cable tie mount point for wire tie down and to provide strain relief for connections on the board.
Added channel to fit the USB plug onto the board while board is mounted.

Changes 12/18/2016
Removed two wire guides at hotend terminals for wire clearance
Fixed floor thickness error - now 0.125" thick
Added cooling slots on top compartment – also saves material
Drastic board pocket dimensioning corrections. Accounts for normal board dimensional variation (pocket is already print tested)
Added model and drawing for cover
All screw hardware change to M3. Great for commonality and reduces board damage risk
Moved 2.25” wiring opening on fan side to better facilitate the pre-wifi board versions.

author: yblock

title: primitive compounds for OpenSCAD, partial hollow

description.text:
I always try to keep my code lean.
This is why I started to create a library for more complex compounds.
Today it contains:
pyramid
tri_angle
hollow_sphere
hollow_cylinder
hollow_cube
rounded_cube
hollow_rounded_cube

Last edit:
Added lid and bottom as parameters to hollow_cube and hollow_cylinder
Everything is backward compatible.

Any comments, suggestions, improvements or extensions are welcome

See the detailed inline documentation:

rectangular pyramid
x and y may differ on floor and top
possible to create roofs
module pyramid(xFloor=10, yFloor=10, xTop=minVal, yTop=minVal, z=10)


rectangular tri angle, with height
directions 1-3: the rect angle is located at coordinates 0,0,0
direction 0: default, legacy, the rect angle is at x,0
negative values changes direction
direction 1: xy
direction 2: xz
direction 3: yz
module tri_angle(a, b, wall, direction=0)


hollow sphere, outer diameter and wall given
module hollow_sphere(outerDia, wall=1)


hollow cylinder (ring or pipe)
uses r1, r2 as outer perimters and h like normal cylinder
wall means thickness of the wall
center like center of cylinder
lid and bottom: creates round box with lid or bottom
module hollow_cylinder(r1, r2, h, wall, center=false, lid=false, bottom=false)


hollow cube, what else?
outerCube is [X,Y,Z]
wall is thickness of wall
center like center of cube
lid and bottom: creates box with lid or bottom
module hollow_cube(outerCube, wall, center=false, lid=true, bottom=true)


cube with rounded edges and corners, depends on param dimensions
outerCube is [X,Y,Z]
rCorner is the radius of the edges rounding
dimensions 2: 4 edges rounded
dimensions 3: all edges rounded corners as well
module rounded_cube(outerCube, rCorner, dimensions=3)


hollow cube, rounded edges only, what else?
outerCube is [X,Y,Z]
rCorner is the radius of the edges rounding
wall is thickness of wall
lid and bottom: creates box with lid or bottom
module hollow_rounded_cube(outerCube, rCorner, wall, lid=true, bottom=true)

remixed_from.title: Direct-drive hinged extruder for E3D/J-Head hot-end (Prusa i3)

description.text:
Note - Still being actively modified so files may change and things may not work. This is a compact i3 extruder I designed after looking at all the other compact designs on here. I didn't find one I liked that worked with the E3D and the MK7 hobbed pulley so I came up with my own. You will need to print all parts, this does not use a standard X carriage. I was tired of mine failing because of the screws coming loose or other reasons so this one is connect to the extruder in 3 places. Items required: 10 x M3 screws (not sure of lengths right now)
5 x M3 nuts
1 x MK7 Hobbed Pulley (I use the TrinityLabs version)
1 x 623 bearing
1 x Spring (I currently have springs on order from McMaster Carr, currently using 2 out of a assorted pack from Harbor Freight)
3 x LM8UU bearings I am using the short NEMA17 sold by Qu-bd but any NEMA17 with a 5mm shaft should work.

title: Reach 3D Titan Extruder Mount and Prox Sensor

description.text:
Custom Mounts for the Reach 3D Printer to mount the E3D Titan Direct Drive Extruder and Solid 2 hole mounted Proximity Sensor for Finer adjustment than the stock mount.

The Brackets may need a little more tweaking, and if they do not line up quite right, please let me know in the Reach3D G+ Community so I can correct them.

Printer:

Reach 3D Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Resolutions, speeds, and other things are irrelevant, print what you are comfortable with. 0.1 mm Resolution gave a finer appearance to the files for me.

Hardware Needed:

Additional hardware needed are as follows:

2 x M5x50
2 x M5x30
2 x 1/2" 3/8"OD .219 ID Spacers ( Got mine from AluminumSpacers.com Happy with them )

X Limit Switch can use redoing. I did not on mine though, I just clipped the ends of the plastic for mounting hole and made it a slot to work.

Assembly is a bit tricky. Before you mount the Titan and motor to the mount, I found it better to assemble the top left piece to the bracket as it sits behind the motor block. with the M5x50 screw it's Top Proximity Sensor, 1/2" Spacer, V Wheel, 1/4" Spacer, metal block, Titan bracket, X Limit Switch (butt of switch sits on end of bracket), nut. I have a gap in the mount for the motor to allow for the nut. Assemble the Titan per E3D's instructions. Top Right hole is M5x30, V Wheel, 1/4" Spacer, metal plate, Titan bracket, nut. Bottom holes are the same as their respective top holes. Make sure you have your Belt mounted to your X plate prior to mounting bottom Wheels. Assemble and tighten as normal. May I recommend a part cooling fan also with this setup as it will compliment the E3D Hotend. I have 2 things added to my Reach Collection that you can get to serve this purpose. And re-use the 40mm fans Nate included with your Reach. E3D Piggy Back Fan mount. and the 40mm to 30mm adapter plate. I used M3x8 and M3x16 for the brackets and adapter.

In your firmware. Be sure to change your settings for the Extruder Steps per MM as per E3D's specifications. It's a precisely machined Extruder, I found no need to tweak it on my setup.

Now for the Proximity Sensor Offset settings, I used:
"#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -10 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]"
"#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 45 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]"
"#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]"

Y offset is actually 85 but, the printer can't use that setting as it can't move the Hotend far enough. Trust me, 45mm is ok. I also do a 9 point bed level on mine. Not necessary, but to each their own.

Just use the 2 nuts and washers that came with the Prox Sensor to tighten and adjust your height. Once you have it dialed in and tight, you should not have to worry about it again. But it won't hurt to check it from time to time. :-)

These prints were designed using OnShape's Free license. They are public and you may make adjustments as you see fit. Or improve on them. They are crude and designed to get the E3D Hotend functional with the Reach 3D printer.

comments.text: I can try, but it's not going to be easy. I do not have an Aero, so I will not be able to do any test fits to tweak it and when I designed this part, I just started getting into On-shape and the sketches are archaic and crude. The slightest adjustment to any measurement distorts the whole part. Thank you splines... I'm going to have to redesign the whole part to make this work. It'll be a few days though. Work is kinda priority.

comments.text: Hey Kouruu... so I just upgraded to the Titan Aero. I was wondering if you could modify this so it would fit with the Aero. The Aero makes the nozzle quite a bit shorter from the original Titan extruder. I tried fitting it up (it's a fairly simple upgrade) but the nozzle won't clear the distance because of the vwheels, it is that much shorter. I think if you move all 4 holes up by about 20mm and shorten the total height it work.
comments.author: techyg

comments.text: I am trying to get this working. Would you mind posting a picture of how you have it installed? I am not sure if I'm doing it quite right.
comments.author: techyg

comments.text: If you can bear with me until tomorrow evening, due to the time of night. I will try to get some pictures added to the this file. the bracket should line up with the holes on the metal plate and the square slot on the back side, hopefully should line up with the M3Nuts that hold the belt tension bracket on. As the Reach is currently my only printer, it's painful to reprint and tear everything apart every time I make a change. But I have taken new measurements and adjusted my file each time I've made a revision. You will definitely need the hardware I've listed on the details page to use this bracket. I didn't mention in instructions, but I actually found it a lot easier for the X Limit Switch to move it to the back side with the Proximity Holder and flipped the screw to the back side as well. Assembling the 2 top V wheels to the metal plate and bracket before you mount the titan extruder will make assembly a lot easier on you. Once you have the extruder and top v wheels assembled, then, feed in your belt and rest on the 2020 and assemble the bottom wheels. Then tighten everything up. Adjusting the proximity sensor will take some trial and error. It's best to manually lower the Z axis and get the sensor close. Then keep autohoming and adjusting the sensor until your autohome puts your Z at the right height (where you can just put a business card underneath.) If you should have any other problems with mounting it, if you can post pics on the G+ Community where I can see what you have and I can better assist. I hope this helps.

description.text:
I made a new extruder top for the Bowden extruder that came on my Tevo Tarantula so it will feed flexible filament. I have not tried Ninjaflex, but it works great with Makerflex from Makergeeks. As you can see in the photo, it is basically a copy of the original with tighter tolerances so the filament can not escape out the sides instead of feeding into the tube. The hole for the tube fitting is for a 6mm thread fitting. I used a different fitting, but the original one should fit.

Edit: Someone requested the bottom half, so here it is. It is made for 4mm bolts on the roller and spring holder, and the screw that goes into the stepper motor is 3mm.
The roller is 13mm in diameter. It is the one that came with the Tevo.

Have fun and happy printing!

MicroMake D1

No

30% on my print

title: Extruder Jam Clearing Rod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Wanhao offers a similar cleaning rod for 5 dollars. This wheel will allow you to make your own. Buy any 1.6MM-1.7MM piano wire and make your own cleaning rod for much less. This can be used with many printers but is intended for any Wanhao I3/Monoprice Select IIIP. On my Anet A6, I have to remove the extruder motor to use it. Unfortunately, it seems the hot end doesn't have a direct path from the extruder motor to the hot end. It works well at forcing broken filament or jams out of the hot end. I use it together with a flexible drill bit and have had great success. (See parts below.) Nothing is more frustrating than a clogged nozzle, especially for beginners. This thing simplifies clearing jams especially when used together with the flexible drill bits.

The bottom of the blue tape marks the point where the rod reaches all the way to the hot end nozzle on my printer. I used tape but you can mark it with a permanent marker or the like.

The wheel provided, allow you to bend your own piece of piano wire and make your own tool. The holes allows you to use 2 or more needle nose pliers to bend the wire to conform to a circular shape. The center hole of the wheel is used to bend the corner (between the circle end and the straight rod. See my pictures.

If anyone living near Cincinnati Ohio needs piano wire, I still have plenty of extra that I can sell at minimal cost. I recommend a 15-17CM piece of piano wire. 5MM of that will be used for the top bend.

The key is to push the filament through quickly and somewhat forcefully. Don't leave the cleaning rod in the hot end for very long to prevent getting the hot filament up near the cold part of the hot end or on the PTFE tube.

Parts:

Unlike other drill bits that break, flexible drill bits don't, atleast not for me after several uses.

Flexible drill bit .4MM size. (Highly Recommended) https://www.amazon.com/3maker-Extruder-Nozzle-Printer-Cleaning/dp/B01EN5B9G6/ref=sr_1_3?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1482036668&sr=1-3&keywords=.4mm+trigorilla

Flexible drill bit .3MM size. (Highly Recommended)
https://www.amazon.com/3maker-Extruder-Nozzle-Printer-Cleaning/dp/B01EN5B83A/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1482036595&sr=8-5&keywords=.3mm+trigorilla

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

print_settings.Notes:: For the icicles and the socket, I used 0 infill and 0.6 for the shell.  I used only a solid top fill to leave the bottom open  The center and the cap were 10% infill with the same shell and both top and bottom solid.  You can use supports for the center, but I got by with using direct cooling.  The PLA bridged very well.  I used Cura and SeeMeCNC translucent blue PLA.with a 200° extruder and 50° bed with glue stick on glass.

description.text: A late entry for anyone still wanting a tree topper. Using a battery powered light set from Target, I made a translucent star with internal twinkling lights. It is an involved project, but simple and fun! Here is a video of the twinkling lights! https://youtu.be/THbDZfwUzMw

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

varies by part

Notes:

For the icicles and the socket, I used 0 infill and 0.6 for the shell. I used only a solid top fill to leave the bottom open The center and the cap were 10% infill with the same shell and both top and bottom solid. You can use supports for the center, but I got by with using direct cooling. The PLA bridged very well. I used Cura and SeeMeCNC translucent blue PLA.with a 200° extruder and 50° bed with glue stick on glass.

Assembly

You will need 3 of the large spikes and 4 of the small spikes. Print all the parts and drill a small hole in the top of the socket to run the wire through. Get the Philips Warm White Twinkling Dewdrop Light set line in the picture ($6.99 on sale at Target). Feed the entire light string up through the socket. By folding the string of lights, you can distribute the lights between the different points of the star. Take your time, you want to distribute them as evenly as possible. Assemble with superglue. Use as little as possible, this is purely decorative. I glued mine together before stringing the lights, but I think it would be easier to glue last. The lights that are left can be coiled into the center for effect.

This is the light set you want from Target.

Design steps

Most of this was designed in TinkerCad. I used the Make#6 Classic Icicle model from Faberdashery located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:196653

I created the center and experimented until I got the two sizes of icicles to fit properly. The cap was an afterthought, but it finishes the project nicely.
